description.narrative: LCMGDM is visible in 32 municipalities and 14 capital cities as an experience of social mobilisation and peace pedagogy that encourage citizen participation and public deliberation through a diverse series of dialogues on issues related to the conflict and collective peace building process.

Internationella Organisationen för Migration (IOM) har ansökt om finansiering för att genomföra projektet “World´s Largest Conversation”. Projektets syfte är att uppmuntra civilt deltagande och öppen debatt under övergången till ett post-konfliktscenario och fredsbyggnadsprocessen på landsbygden. Jämställdhet och miljö kommer utgöra två viktiga teman. Projektet har tre faser: (1) en medvetandegörandekampanj för att folk ska känna till initiativet och hur de kan delta, (2) stöd och diskussion på de platser dialogerna äger rum och (3) civil deltagande för att främja fred. När det gäller resultat på impact-nivå år projektets mål att 1 % av befolkningen i de 32 kommunerna och 14 storstäderna känner till kommunikationssatsningen och dess verksamhetsfält.

LCMGDM is a social mobilization and education plan designed by a working group (the “Pedagogy Group for Peace- GPP”) within the Minister Counselor for Communications of the Presidency to encourage citizen participation and public deliberation during the transition to a post-conflict scenario and the territorial peace building process. The project has three phases: (1) an awareness campaign for people to know about the initiative and how they can participate, (2) support and deliberation where the dialogues take place and (3) civil mobilization in favour of peace. Gender and Environment will be two fundamental issues. As to the impact result, the project aims at achieving that 1% of the population from the 32 municipalities and 14 capital cities recognize LCMGDM and its spaces.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project was to promote conversation skills among the Colombian population as a tool for peace building. The means for doing so, was through a communications campaign named "the World's Largest Conversation" that was lead by the Peace Pedagogy Team within the Colombian Presidency. The idea was then to (1) generate brand-awareness for the "World's Largest Conversation Campaign" through the creation of digital pieces and TV and radio spots and (2) to promote conversation abilities among the Colombian citizens of selected municipalities. It is worth mentioning, the Embassy's funds were targeted to the media communication campaign (i.e. production and broadcast of radio spots, videos, promotional pieces etc). Nonetheless, it is important to mention the accomplishments of the "World's Largest Conversation" in the pedagogy aspect, as the whole purpose of the communication campaign was to maximize their conversation methodology for peace building. By the end of the campaign, the results were: Brand awareness By the end of the project, a poll was conducted by the National Consulting Center, and it concluded that in the cities and municipalities where the campaign took place, 7% of the population knew about the campaign and recognized its spaces and digital pieces. See answer to next question for specific information on the produced pieces and reached population. Promotion of communication skills 1. Public Servants: World's Largest Conversation team designed an itinerant exhibition, where information on the social and political context of the armed conflict and negotiation agenda with the FARC was given. Additionally, reflections over public administration's role on peace building were posed. The exhibition was presented in 27 national agencies. 2. Education: through the initiative "la Paz es una nota", the project generated spaces for reflecting upon the role of education sector in the construction of a "peace culture" through the construction of a national agenda on peace education. 3. Local authorities: work with local authorities focused on reflecting how to implement local peace building measures. The team from the World's Largest Conversation participated in national assemblies of local authorities (Mayors and Governors) with the aim of identifying the regional "pending conversations" related to peace building. Through these initiative, it was identified that priority topics for the regions are: rural development (25%), social investment and eradication of poverty (16%), access to education (10%), victims' reparation (6%). 4. "Conversation schools": through this initiative young leaders were trained to be "conversation ambassadors" through capacity building on the peace process with the FARC, use of IT for the design and widespread of pro-peace activities and conversation as a tool for dealing with social conflicts. By the end of the project, 594 ambassadors were trained in 11 departments (Cundinamarca 4, Santander 34, Antioquia 33, Valle del Cauca 128; Bolivar 34, Atlántico 53, Caldas 32, Meta 51, Risaralda 60, Cauca 94, Magdalena 43)
